content.title: Cervical Spondylotic Myelopathy
content.summary: Cervical spondylotic myelopathy (CSM) is spinal cord dysfunction resulting from degenerative narrowing of the cervical spinal canal. It is the most common cause of spinal cord dysfunction in adults over 55. Presenting features include gait difficulty, hand clumsiness, and upper motor neuron signs. Surgical decompression is typically required for progressive or moderate-severe myelopathy.
key_points: Most common cause of spinal cord dysfunction in older adults; from degenerative spondylosis
Hallmark symptoms: gait difficulty, hand clumsiness, neck stiffness, rarely pain
Signs: spastic gait, hyperreflexia, Hoffman sign, Babinski sign, hand weakness/atrophy
MRI shows cord compression with or without T2 signal change (myelomalacia)
Natural history: stepwise decline; rarely improves spontaneously
Surgery indicated for moderate-severe myelopathy or progression; anterior vs posterior approach
content.statement: CSM is a progressive condition requiring early recognition and often surgical intervention to prevent irreversible spinal cord damage. The diagnosis should be considered in any older adult with gait difficulty and upper motor neuron signs.

explanation.intuition: Degenerative changes in the cervical spine (disc herniation, osteophytes, ligamentum flavum hypertrophy) narrow the spinal canal. When the cord is compressed, ischemia and mechanical damage cause myelopathy. Long-term compression leads to irreversible cord damage (gliosis, myelomalacia).
explanation.key_insight: Unlike radiculopathy (radiating arm pain), myelopathy presents with gait difficulty and hand incoordination. Pain is often minimal. The absence of pain can delay diagnosis. T2 hyperintensity in the cord on MRI indicates myelomalacia, which is a poor prognostic sign.
explanation.technical_details: Clinical assessment: modified Japanese Orthopaedic Association (mJOA) score grades severity (18 normal; 12-17 mild; 9-11 moderate; <9 severe). MRI findings: canal stenosis, cord compression, T2 signal change (poor prognostic factor), cord atrophy. Surgical options: anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF), posterior laminoplasty or laminectomy fusion.

definitions_glossary.cervical_spondylotic_myelopathy: CSM: spinal cord dysfunction from degenerative cervical canal stenosis
definitions_glossary.spondylosis: Age-related degenerative changes in spine: disc degeneration, osteophytes, facet arthropathy
definitions_glossary.myelopathy: Spinal cord dysfunction manifesting as UMN signs, gait impairment, sensory changes
definitions_glossary.upper_motor_neuron_signs: Hyperreflexia, spasticity, Babinski sign, clonus from corticospinal tract involvement
definitions_glossary.hoffman_sign: Reflex finger flexion when flicking middle finger DIP; indicates cervical myelopathy
definitions_glossary.lhermitte_sign: Electric sensation down spine with neck flexion; indicates cervical cord pathology
definitions_glossary.hand_clumsiness: Difficulty with fine motor tasks from corticospinal and posterior column dysfunction
definitions_glossary.myelomalacia: Spinal cord softening/gliosis from chronic compression; T2 hyperintense on MRI
definitions_glossary.anterior_cervical_discectomy: ACDF: surgical removal of disc and fusion from anterior approach
definitions_glossary.laminoplasty: Posterior decompression creating 'hinge' to expand spinal canal while preserving motion
definitions_glossary.cervical_canal_stenosis: Narrowing of spinal canal, typically <10mm AP diameter causes myelopathy
definitions_glossary.mjoa_score: Modified Japanese Orthopaedic Association score: functional assessment of myelopathy severity

pathophysiology.mechanism: Cervical spondylosis causes canal stenosis through: (1) disc degeneration and herniation, (2) osteophyte formation (bone spurs), (3) ligamentum flavum hypertrophy, (4) facet joint hypertrophy. Cord compression leads to ischemia (vascular compromise) and direct mechanical injury. Chronic compression causes demyelination, axonal loss, and gliosis (myelomalacia).
key_pathways: Degenerative changes → cervical canal stenosis → cord compression
Cord compression → ischemia + mechanical injury → myelopathy
Dynamic factors: flexion/extension can worsen compression
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: CSM typically progresses stepwise with periods of stability. Without treatment, most patients deteriorate. Early surgery before severe deficit offers best outcomes. T2 signal change indicates poorer prognosis.

severity_grading.mjoa_score: 18 points total: motor function upper/lower extremity, sensory, bladder

imaging.mri: Gold standard: shows cord compression, T2 signal change, canal diameter
imaging.ct_myelography: Alternative if MRI contraindicated; shows bony detail
imaging.xray: Shows alignment, instability; flexion-extension views for dynamic stenosis

conservative_management.monitoring: Clinical exam and MRI every 6-12 months

indications: Significant cord compression with T2 signal change

anterior_approach.acdf: Anterior cervical discectomy and fusion: 1-3 level disease
anterior_approach.corpectomy: For extensive posterior osteophytes or multi-level disease

posterior_approach.laminoplasty: Expands canal while preserving motion; lordotic spine required
posterior_approach.advantages: Better for multi-level disease, preserved lordosis

surgical_treatment.outcomes: 70-80% improve with surgery; best outcomes if operated early; T2 changes predict poorer recovery

skos.definition: Spinal cord dysfunction resulting from degenerative narrowing of the cervical spinal canal causing compression of the spinal cord

icd10.display: Other spondylosis with myelopathy, cervical region

learning_objectives: Recognize the clinical presentation of cervical spondylotic myelopathy
Perform bedside examination for myelopathy signs (Hoffman, Babinski, gait)
Interpret MRI findings in CSM including T2 signal change significance
Apply indications for surgical versus conservative management
Understand surgical approaches (anterior vs posterior) for CSM
clinical_pearls: Gait difficulty + hand clumsiness + hyperreflexia in older adult = think CSM
Hoffman sign: flick middle finger DIP → thumb/index flexion = positive
Pain is often minimal; absence of pain delays diagnosis
T2 hyperintensity in cord = myelomalacia = worse prognosis even after surgery
Natural history: stepwise decline; rarely improves spontaneously
Earlier surgery = better outcomes; don't wait for severe myelopathy
common_misconceptions: CSM presents with pain (often minimal or absent)
Conservative treatment stops progression (usually progresses without surgery)
Radiculopathy and myelopathy are the same (radiculopathy = nerve root; myelopathy = cord)
